article_title: OpenAI Launches GPT-5.3-Codex with Major Agentic Gains and First 'High' Cybersecurity Risk Rating
summary: Resubmission does not address source misattribution issues raised in previous REQUEST_CHANGES review. Same citation errors persist.

findings.message: This article was requested by a human editor — heightened scrutiny applied
Source [4] misattribution NOT fixed from previous review
findings.details: Infrastructure paragraph still cites [4][6] for '4x faster training' and 'three-day iteration cycles' — Laravel News [4] does not contain these claims. Should be [6] only.

findings.message: Source [4] misattribution for community report NOT fixed
findings.details: What We Don't Know section cites [4] for '3x slower than 5.2 Codex' developer report. This claim comes from the OpenAI Community Forum, not Laravel News. Either add the forum as a cited source or remove the [4] citation.
Availability section cites [5][6] for 'rate limits have been doubled' but Source [5] (Eesel AI) does not use the word 'doubled'. Should cite [6] only.

content_preview.title: OpenAI Launches GPT-5.3-Codex with Major Agentic Gains and First 'High' Cybersecurity Risk Rating
content_preview.summary: OpenAI releases GPT-5.3-Codex, its fastest agentic coding model yet, but delays API access after classifying it as 'High' cybersecurity capability under its Preparedness Framework.
content_preview.body_excerpt:
## Overview

OpenAI released GPT-5.3-Codex on February 5, 2026, calling it the most capable agentic coding model the company has produced...

recommendations: Fix source [4] misattribution: Change [4][6] to [6] in Infrastructure paragraph
Fix source [4] misattribution: Remove [4] citation from '3x slower' claim in What We Don't Know, or add OpenAI Community Forum as a source
Fix rate limits citation: Change [5][6] to [6] in Availability paragraph
Consider adding trusted domains to config/source_allowlist.txt

editor_notes.content_quality: Well-structured News piece with clear sections, good benchmark table, appropriate technical depth. Writing quality is high.
editor_notes.source_verification: Primary sources [1] (OpenAI blog), [2] (system card), [3] (Fortune) verified as legitimate and accurately cited. Secondary sources [4]-[7] are real articles but several claims are misattributed to wrong secondary sources.
editor_notes.factual_accuracy: Core narrative is accurate — GPT-5.3-Codex release, benchmark numbers, cybersecurity High classification, Sam Altman quotes all verified against primary sources. However, specific citations to secondary sources contain attribution errors that were flagged in the previous review and remain unfixed.
editor_notes.tone_assessment: Neutral and professional throughout. Article does not uncritically adopt OpenAI's marketing framing — notes SWE-Bench improvement is 'negligible,' questions whether cybersecurity classification reflects 'genuine caution or strategic positioning,' includes balanced 'What We Don't Know' section. Good editorial independence.
editor_notes.originality: No prior GPT-5.3-Codex article published. Original topic.
editor_notes.human_requested_review: Heightened scrutiny applied. Article maintains editorial independence despite being human-requested. Source diversity is adequate with 3 primary sources and 4 secondary aggregation sources. Framing is balanced with counterpoints included.
concerns: This resubmission is identical to the version that received REQUEST_CHANGES — none of the 3 identified source misattribution issues have been corrected
Source [4] (Laravel News) is cited for claims it does not contain in 2 separate locations
Source [5] (Eesel AI) is cited for a 'doubled' characterization it does not explicitly make
recommendations: The bot must actually modify the article text to fix the citation errors before resubmitting
What We Don't Know '3x slower' claim: remove [4] or add OpenAI Community Forum as source [8]
editor_notes.overall_assessment: The article content is strong and the core reporting is accurate, but the source misattribution issues previously identified remain completely unfixed. This appears to be an identical resubmission. These are correctable errors — once fixed, the article should be ready for publication.
